turn.text: And by the time the case -- by the time the case comes to the Supreme Court, your first terminology was correct is, he stands convicted when he comes with a conviction.

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: Well all these cases come before the Court, Your Honor, now where their conviction is reversed.
If this Court reverses the Whorton case, unless there's some other error on remand other than this per se business here, the conviction stands of -- the conviction will then become affirmed.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Your prediction is that a plea reversed and said Taylor is a totality case depending on the circumstances and their ultimate issue being whether there's a fair trial in the particular case, as my brother Powell says?
That the Kentucky court would probably revoke this rule?

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: I don't know that they would revoke this rule which is a prospective effect.
But as to these 50 or more cases in the pipeline right now, many, many of them I feel the convictions will be affirmed.

The Kentucky Court of Appeals which is a lower court below the Kentucky Supreme Court affirmed two criminal convictions after Taylor came down, but before the decision in Whorton came down, they distinguished the Taylor case.
They didn't think it was a per se rule at all, and they distinguished it and affirmed the convictions.
And I think this is what will happen in many of the Court of Appeals cases and Kentucky Supreme Court cases that have now been automatically reversed due to what we feel is a basic misinterpretation.
Whether Kentucky Supreme Court wants to change the criminal rule that they amended and that is so hastily, I don't know.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But Mr. Attorney General, can we decide what they said as well as you can?
You're trying to tell us what they said.
We can read that, can't we?

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: Yes, I can only give my ideas of what they said, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh!
It's okay.

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: That's all I have.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Can I ask you one more question?

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: Certainly, Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you have a list of the -- I take it you have list of the cases that might be affected, the past convictions?

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: Yes, we'll get it, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I don't want the list, but what's the oldest one?

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: The oldest one?
The oldest one of course in progression in appeal would be this one.
The most recent one is a conviction for a murder case for the accused got the death penalty.
And it's now pending before the Kentucky Supreme Court and will be, if things go as they are, will be automatically reversed.
There are 29 issues in that particular case.
The first one is a presumption of innocence, instruction was requested and denied.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You're talking about cases on direct appeal?

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: I'm talking about cases, yes, they are going to retry to delay the cases in the sense that we ask all the procedural things like petitions for rehearing and this and that, because what has happened is we've been getting blocked up with all these cases trying to keep them alive until they get to this Court and hoping for a decision from this Court.
If we lose, so be it on the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why are there a lot of other cases that might come up on collateral attack?

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: We don't know, because we don't know the detail of when these have come up or not because it would depend upon whether the instruction was requested or not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You're only talking now about “X” number that are on direct appeal?

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: Right, and from time to time the most recent case was about two weeks ago that came to our attention.
There may be others as they come in from the state on the process of going up in the appellate system.
When we originally pursued this litigation we guess -- we made a guesstimate, 20 to 80 to get --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But there may be a lot of cases that will be subject to state and then federal collateral attack.

turn.speaker: patrick_b_kimberlin_iii
turn.label: Mr. Patrick B. Kimberlin III
turn.text: It certainly could be, it certainly could be, although we don't know the -- any exact number of course.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
